div.p:
XVIII - 49 53
Hence the cry of the Herald
"give us sleep -" It is remarkable
how anxious ^ for peace those who
have been fighting all their
lives appear to be for peace
In this respect the expressions
of strong desire of both the
Makololo and Boers of
the CashanMagaliesberg mountains
who are perpetually making
forays are identical - Indeed
MsersMessrs. Hendrick Potgeiter &
Pretorius conscientiously
believed themselves to be
fumore fully entitled to the
name and blessing of
"Peace-makers" than any
missionary in the country -

When Sekeletu was
installed in into the chieftainship
he felt his position rather
insecure for it was believed
that the incantations
of Mpepe had an intimate
connection with Sebituane's
death - Indeed the latter had
said to his son "that hut of
incantation will prove fatal
to either you or me" -

When the Mambari ofin
1850 took home a favourable
report of this new market
to the West a number of half
breed Portuguese slave traders
50 54
were induced to come in 1853
and one who appeared to resembled
closely a real Portuguese coming
with them came to Linyanti
while I was there - The latter
This man had no merchandise and
pretended to have come in
order to enquire "what sort
of goods were necessary
for the market - " He seemed
much disconcerted put about by my
presence there - Sekeletu gave
presented him with him the present of an ox
and an elephantselephant's tusk
and when he washad departed
about fifty miles to the
Westward he carried off
an entire village of the
Bakalahari belonging to the
Makololo - He had a number
of armed slaves with him
and as all both ^ the villagers men women
and children, were removed
and the fact was unknown
untilluntil a considerable time afterwards
it is not knowncertain whether
his object was obtained
by violence or by fair
promises - In either case
slavery must have been
their position ^ of these poor people - He was carried
in a hammock slung between
two poles which appearing to be
a bag - The Makololo named
him "Father of the bag" -

Mpepe favoured these slave traders
and they as is usual with
them founded all their hopes
of influence and success
on his disaffection - My
arrival on the scene was
felt to be so much weight
in the scale against their
interests - A large party of Mambari
had come were atto Linyanti when
I was floundering on the
prairies south of the Chobe -
As the news ^ of my being in the
neighbourhood ^ reached them
their countenances fell but
and when some who had
assisted us to cross the river
returned with hats which I
had given them they at once
betook themselves to
preciptateprecipitate flight - It is
usual for visitors to
ask formal leavepermission before
attempting to leave a chief
but the sight of the hats
made the Mambari pack
up at once - The Makololo
enquired the cause of the hurry
and were told that if I found
them there I wshould take all
their slaves and goods from them and though assured
by Sekeletu that I was a not
a robber but a man of peace they fled
my presence ^ by night while that I
was still 60 miles off -
52 56
They went to the North where
under the ^ countenanceprotection of Mpepe
they had erected a stockade
of considerable size - There
several native half breed
slave traders under the leadership
of a native Portuguese carried
on their traffic without
reference to the chief into
whose country they had
unceremoniously introduced
themselves - While Mpepe
feeding them with the cattle
of Sekeletu formed a plan
of raising himself by means
of their firearms to the be
the head of the Makololo -
It is The usual course the
slave traders adopt is to take
a part in the political affairs
of each tribe, and siding
with the strongest get well
paid by captures made
from the weaker party -
Long conferences were
held with Mpepe and it was
deemed advisable for him
to strike the first blow so he
provided himself with a
small battle axe with the
intention of cutting Sekeletu
down the first time they
met -

My object being first
of all to examine the
country for a healthy locality
before attempting to make
a new path to either the East
or West coasts - I proposed
to Sekeletu the plan of
ascending the great river
which we had observed
in 18571 - He volunteered to
accompany me and when
we got about 60 miles away
on ourthe road to Sesheke we
encountered Mpepe - The Makololo
like most Bechuanas though possessing
abundance of cattle
used had
never attempted to ride oxen
untilluntil I had had advised
it in 1851 - The Bechuanas
generally were in the same
condition untilluntil Europeans
came among them and
imparted the idea of riding -
All their journeys were performed
on foot - - Sekeletu and his
companions were all
mounted on oxen though
having neither saddle nor
bridle they were perpetually
falling off - Mpepe armed
with his little axe met us
^ came along a
path parallel
to but a quarter
of a mile distant
from that of o our party but it and when
he saw Sekeletu ^ he ran with
all his might towards
us but Sekeletu being
on his gaurdguard galloped
54 58
off to an adjacent village - He
then went out of the way somewhere
till all our party came up -
Mpepe had given his own
party to understand that he
would cut down Sekeletu
either on their first meeting
or at their breaking up of
their first conference - The
former ^ intention out having been impossible
thus frustrated, he
determined to effect
his purpose after
their first conference - I happened to sit down
between the two in the hut
where they met - Being tired
with riding all day in
the sun I asked Sekeletu
where I should sleep and
he replied "Come I will shewshow
you" As we rose together
I unconsciously covered
Sekeletu's body with mine
and saved him from
the blow of the assassin
I knew nothing but
remarked that all MpepesMpepe's
men kept hold of their
arms even after we ^ werehad
sat siat down a thing quite
unusual in the presence
of chief - And when Sekeletu
shewedshowed me the hut in which
I was to spend the night he
remarked "that man wishes
to kill me" - I afterwards learnt that Somesome of Mpepe's
attendants had divulged the
secret and, influencedbearing in mind
55 59
by his father's instructions Sekeletu
put Mpepe to death that night
It was managed so quietly
that although ^ I was sleeping asleep within a few
yards of the scene I knew
nothing of it till the next day -
Nokuane went to the fire at
which Mpepe sat with a
handful of snuff as if he
were about to sit down
and regale himself - Mpepe
said to him "Nsepisa" cause me
to take a pinch - and as he held
out his hand ^ Nokuane ^ caught hold of
it that while another man
seized the oppositeother hand and leading
him out a mile speared him -
This is the common mode
of executing a criminal-s
They are not allowed to speak
but on one ^ occasion a man feeling his
wrist held too tightly said
"Hold me gently cantcan't you,
you will soon be led out
in the same way yourselfves""
Mpepe's men fled to the
Barotse and it being
unadvisable for us to
go thither during the com-
motion which followed
on Mpepe's death we
returned to Linyanti -

Cases such as theThe foregoing
may be considered as ^ a fair specimen of ^ the
mode of dealing with grave
political offences - In common
cases there is a greater shewshow
of deliberation - The complainant
asks the man against
whom he means to lodge his
complaint to come with him
to the chief - This is ^ never refused
by no one - When both are in
the Kotla the complainant
stands up and states the
whole case before the chief
and ^ the people usually assembled
there - He stands a few seconds
after he has done this to
recollect if he has forgotten
anything - The witnesses
to whom he has referred
then rise up and tell all
they ^ themselves saw or heard but not
anything they heard from
others - When The defendant
then rises after allowing
some minutes to elapse
so that he may not
interrupt any of the
opposite party slowly
rises folds his kcloak
around him and in the
most quiet deliberate way
he can assume begins to
explain away the case
57 61
deny^ing the charge or admit^ting it as
the case may be - Frequently
Sometimes when
galled by in the course of his remarks
the complainant utters a
sentence of dissent - ComplainantThe accused
turns quietly to him and says
"Be quietsilent, I sat still while you
were speaking - CantCan't you do the
same - ? Do you want to have
it all to yourself"? & and as the
audience acquiesce in this
chafing and enforce silence
he goes on till he has finished
all he wishes to say in his
defence - If he has any
witnesses to the truth ^ of the facts of his
defence they give their evidence
No oath is administered
but occasionally when a
statement is questioned a
man will say "By my father"
or "By the chief it is so - " Their
truthfulness among each other
is quite remarkable - but
their system of government
is such that Europeans
are not in a position to
realize it readily - A poor
man will say in his
defence, against a rich one
will say "I am astonished
to hear a man so great
as he tell make a false
accusation" as if the offence
58 62
of falsehood were felt to be one against
the society which the individual
referred to had the greatest
interest in upholding -

If the case is one of
no importance the chief decides
it at once - If frivolous he
may give the complainant
a scolding or& burst into
put a stop to the case it in the middle of the complaint
or he may allow it to go
on without paying any
attention to it whatever
Family quarrels are often
treated in this way and then
a man may be seen
stating his case with great
fluency and not a soul
listening to him But if
it is a case between influential
men or brought on by
influential men which
then the greatest decorum
prevails, If the chief does
not see his way clear
to a decision he remains
silent - The elders then rise
one and by one and give
their opinions often in
the way of advice rather
than as decisions
and when the chief finds
the general sentiment
agreeing in one view
59 63
he delivers his judgement
accordingly - He alone speaks
sitting - all others stand -

No one refuses to
acquiesce in the decision of
the chief on account of
his having the power of
life and death in the his
hands to enforce it if he
chooses - but h grumbling
is allowed

This system was found
as well ^ or better developed among
the Makololo thanas among
the Bakwains ^ or even better and is no
foreign ^ importation - When at
Cassange my men had
a little ^ slight quarrel among
themselves and came to
me as to their chief person
there for judgement - This
had occurred often several
times before so without
a thought I went out
of the Portuguese merchantsmerchant's
house in which I was
a guest, sat down and
heard the complaint Vversusand
defence in the usual
way - When I had given
my decision in the
60 64
common hortatory form,
they went off apparently
satisfied - Several Portuguese
who had been viewing the
proceedings with great
interest and complimented
me on the success of my
teaching - but I could
not take any credit
to myself for the system
which ^ had I ^ had found ready
made to my hands

Soon after our arrival
at Linyanti Sekeletu took
me aside and pressed me
to mention those things I loved
best and hoped to get from
him - Anything either in or
out of his town would be
freely given if I would only
mention it I explained
to him that my object was to makelevate him
and his people to be Christians
but he replied he did not
wish to learn to read
the book for he was afraid
61 65
"it might change his heart
and make him content
with one wife ^ only like Sechele"
It was of little use to urge that
the change of heart implied
a contentment ^ with one wife equal to his
present complacency in polygamy
and that Such a preference
after the change of
mind could not be
realized by him
noany more than that
the real unmistakable
pleasure inof religious
services
by any one
can be realized by
those who have not
experienced that great
change of mind & affections
called the "new heart" I assured him that Nnothing was required
expected but by his own
voluntary decision - "No, no
he wanted always to have
five at least - " His ideas
of the state happiness of "holy matrimony"
were on a par with
those of a Portuguese gentleman on the happiness of the state of bliss
whom I met who "did not
like the idea of going to
heaven to be standing", (as
in the pictures), "gazing up
at a glace of light" or of one of
our own
countrymen
who thought
the employment
of heaven was
singing and
praising on a
bare cloud
without anything
to eat or drink - I liked
the frankness of Sekeletu,
for nothing is so wearing
to the spirit as talking to
those who agree with
everything advanced

Sekeletu according
to the system of the Bechuanas
became possessor of
his fathersfather's wives and
adopted two of them -
The children by these women
are however ^ in such cases termed brother
When an elder brother dies
tothe same thing occurs
in respect of his wives
62 66
the brother next in age takes
them among
the Jews and the children that may
be born of those women
he calls his brothers also - As
was the He ^ thus raises up seed
to his departed relative -
An uncle of Sekeletu being a
younger brother of Sebituane
got that chieftain's chief
head ^ wife - or queen - There is
always one who enjoys
this title - Her hut is called
the great house and her
children inherit the chieftain-
-ship - If she dies another a
new wife is selected for the same
position and enjoys the
same privileges though
she shemay happen to be a much younger woman
than the rest.

The majority of the
wives of Sebituane were
given to influential under
-chiefs and in reference
to their early casting off the
widowswidow's weeds a song
was sung saying it was
the men alone felt the loss
of their father Sebituane the
women were so soon
supplied with new husbands
that their hearts had not time
to become sore with grief

63 67
The women complain that
the proportions between the
sexes are so changed now
that they are not valued
as they deserve - The majority
of the real Makololo have
been cut off by fever - Those
who now remain are a
mere fragment of those
who came to the North
with Sebituane - Coming
from a very healthy climate
in the South they were more
subject obnoxious to the febrile
diseases of the valley in
which where which we found them
than the black tribes which
they conquered - In comparison
with the Barotse, Batoka,
and Banyeti, the Makololo
have a sickly hue - They
are of a light brownish
yellow colour while the tribes
referred to are very dark
with a slight tinge of olive.
The whole of the coloured
tribes consider that beauty
and fairness are associated
and women long for children
of light colour so much that
they sometimes chew the bark
of a certain tree in
hopes of producing that
effect - To my eye the
X It will be quite
sufficient to say --
-- The women generally
escaped the fever -
but they are less
fruitful than
formerly - and
to their complaint
64 68
the dark colour is much more
agreableagreeable then the tawyny hue
of the half breed which that
X
* (render into)
Greek - of the Makololo ladies closely
resembles - The fever has
spared them * on account
of the menstruation
being excessively
profuse but they are
less fruitful and to their
insinuation complaint of being undervalued
on account of the disproportion
of the sexes ^ they now add their regrets sorrowful
complaint afflication ofat the want of children
ofof whom they all are excessively
fond -

The Makololo women
work but little - Indeed the
families of that nation
are spread over the country
one or two only in each
village as the lords of the
land - They - all possess
have lordship ^ over great numbers of the
subjected tribes who pass by in
the general
name Makalaka and these ^ who
must ^ must are forced to render their certain
services - ^ and They must are obliged to
aid in tilling the soil;
but have each ^ has his own
land under cultivation -
and otherwise islives nearly
independantindependent - They are proud
to be called
Makololo but
the other term
is often used
in reproach
as betokening
inferiority This species
of servitude may be
termed slavery as it has
to be rendered in consequence
of subjection by force
of arms, but it is so
necessarily very mild
65 69
It is so easy ^ for any one who is unkindly
treated to make his escape
to the other tribes that the Makololo
mustare compelled to treat ^ them to a great extent
rather as children
than as slaves as children
Some masters failingwho fail from
some defect of temper or
disposition failing to secure
the affections of these
conquered people frequently find themselves
left ^ without a single servant, ^ X inx consequence
of the absence of
and impossibility
of a fugitive
slave law - and
the readiness
with which they
assist each
other accrossacross
the rivers in
canoes
The Makololo ladies who
are liberal with theirin their presents of milk &
other food, seldom require
to labour except in the
way of beautifying their
own huts - and courtyards
They drink large quantities
of boyaloa which being
the grain called Caffre Sorghum
or DourrhahDourra in a minute
state or subdivision is
very nutritious and gives
that plumpness of form
which is considered beautiful
They dislike being seen together
at their potations by persons
of the opposite sex - They
cutt their wooly hair
quite short and delight in
having the whole person
shining with butter - Their
dress is a kilt reaching
to the knees; its material is it is made of ox hide
made as soft as cloth the
hairy - It is not ungraceful
66 70
but from the point where
Omit it is fastened round the
lower part of the body upwards
the person ^ with their large pendant breasts is left exposed
A ^ soft skin mantle is thrown
across the shoulders when
the lady is unemployed but
when engaged in any sort
of labour she throws this
aside and works in the
kilt alone - They ornaments
most coveted are
large brass leglets
as thick as the
little finger - ^ and armlets
of both brass
and ivory the
latter often an
inch broad - The
leglets are so
heavy ^ that the ankles
are often blistered
by the weight that
pressesing down
but it is the
fashion and is
borne as mag-
-nanimously
as tight lacing
& ^ tight shoes among
ourselves, Strings
of beads are hung
around the neck
and the fashion ^ -able colours being
light green & pink
a trader could get ^ almost any
thing he chose for beads of these colours

At our public religious
services in the Kotla the
Makololo women always
believed with decorum from
the first except at the
conclusion of the prayer -
When the restall kneeledt
down many of those who
had children in following
the example of the rest
bent over their little ones -
The children in terror of
being crushed to death
set up a simultaneous
yell which so tickled
the whole assembly
there was often a subdued
titter to be let outturned into a
hearty laugh as soon
as they heard, Amen - This
was not so difficult
to overcome in them as
similar peccadilloes were
in the case of ^ the women
67 71
farther south - Long after we
had settled at Mabotsa
when preaching ofn the most
solemn subjects a woman
would be observed to look
round and see^ -ing a neighbour
seated on her dress -, Sheshe of
course gave her a hunch
with the elbow to make
her move off - The other
returned ^ it the push with
interest and perhaps the
remark "take the nasty
thing to youaway will you"
Then three or four began
to huzzle hustle the first offenders
and the men to swear
at them all by way of
enforcing silence

Great numbers of little
trifling things like these occur
and would not be worth
the recital but that one
cannot form a correct
idea of missionary work
except by examination
of the minutiae - And aAt the
risk of appearing frivolous
to some I shall continue
to descend to mere trifles

The numbers who
attended byat the proclamationsummons
by the herald ^ who acted as
beadle were often
from 500 to 700, The service
68 72
consisted of reading a small
portion of the bibleBible and
giving an explanatory address
usually short enough to
prevent weariness or want
of attention - So long as we
continue to hold services
in the Kotla the associations
of the place are unfavourable
to solemnity hence it is
always desirable to have
a place of worship as soon
as possible - And it is
desirable to of importance
too to treat that ^ such place with
reverence - as an aid to secure
that serious attention which
religious subjects demand
This will appear more
evident when it is recollected
that in the very spot where
we may have had been engaged
in acts of devotion
half an hour beforeafter, a
dance willwould be got up
and such arrangementsarrangements which cannot be at once
opposed without the feeling
being produced of exercising
too much authority over
them - It is always unwise
to hurt their feelings of
independaence - Much greater
influence will be gained by
studying how you may
69 73
induce them to act aright with
the impression that they are
doing it of their own free will
Our services arehaving necessarily
been all in the open air - where it is
most difficult to address large bodies of people
prevented my
recovering so
entirely from
the effects of
clergymen's
sore throat so
much as I
expected when
the uvula was
excised at
the Cape

# To give an idea of the
system adopted for months
together on other days as well
as on Sundays - I may advert
to treating the sick for com-
plaints too dwhich seemed to ^ surmount try
the skill of their own doctors
I refrained going to any
one unless his own doctor
wished it or had given up
the case - This led to my
having a selection of the
severer cases only, and
prevented ^ the doctors were notbeing offended
by my taking their practice
out of their hands - When
attacked by fever myself
and wishing to ascertain
what their practices were
I could safely intrustentrust myself
in their hands on account
of their well known friendly
feelings - Their plan is
to produce by means of
medicated vapour baths a profuse
and long continued action
of the skin, which in a
modified form is about
the best way of treating fever

The plan of shewingshowing kindness
to them in their bodily ailments
secures their friendship - This
is not the case ^ to the same degree extent in old missions
where the people have learned
to look upon relief as a right -
a state of things that wasThis sometimes happens among
ourselves at home - Medical
aid is therefore most valuable
in young missions though
at all stages ^ it is a valuable
adjunct to other operations

I proposed to teach
the Makololo to read but
for the reasons mentioned
Sekeletu at first declined
After some weeks however
his father in law and some
others determined to brave
the mysterious book - To
all who have not learned
acquired it ^ the knowledge of letters
is a most quite unfathom-
able - There is nought like
it within the compass of their
observation - and we have
no comparison with
any thing except pictures
to aid them in com-
prehending the idea of signs
of words - It seems to
them supernatural - that
we see in a book things
